Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 10:29AM Seabee wrote: If they find cancer cells or mets in one or more sentinel nodes (some people, like me, have several) they generally remove the rest of the lymph nodes in what is called the "fat pad" in the underarm area.  This may contain a variable number of lymph nodes--some people have more than others, and some pathologists probably do count differenty. My rad onc told me that people have hundreds of lymph nodes altogether, and there is no uniformity about how they are distributed. In your case they found something in the sentinel node and dissected five more to see if it had progressed further, which apparently it hadn't. Since you had a mastectomy, your doctor has concluded that radiation is not necessary.  It is possible that your six nodes were taken out automatically simply because they were located in the underarm breast tissue, in which case you didn't have a full axillary node dissection.  Look at the description of mastectomy on this site and you will see how this can happen.

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 01:20PM Seabee wrote: Genomic health will probably provide some information, as they were very forthcoming when I asked about my low score.  I was told that about 47% of the score was based on HER2 status, so it might depend partly on how negative kmab's HER2 score was.  And yes, this is indicated on the new report form. This is just a guess, but wouldn't the fact that this is kmab's second experience with cancer logically influence her recurrence score, no matter how favorable other signs are? After all, it is recurrence that the Oncotype test is intended to predict, and recurrence negatively influences prognosis.
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX Score - shocked at oncologist recommendation kmab15 otter

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 09:12AM - edited Dec 7, 2008 09:51AM by Seabee kmab-- I assumed that Genomic Health was probably not informed of your earlier experience with BC, but I'm glad you clarified this. However, it is possible that the kind of testing done on the Oncotype Dx test detects a tendency to recur, even after a long interval. That is what the test is about. Since I don't know exactly which genes they test or what their individual signifcance is, I can't say.  They should be able to tell you more  What I meant by your score being influenced by how negative your score was is that the test reports HER2 status on a numerical scale from 7.5 to 13.0, with positive starting at 11.5. This leaves a possible range for negative scores from 7.5  up to 10.7, at which point a narrow strip of "inconclusive" scores begins. I would assume that if your negative score was 10.7, this would give you a higher overall recurrence score than a negative score of 7.5. I was told that the HER2 score comprises 47% of the total recurrence score, so a mere 2 points higher on the HER2 scale might translate to17 points higher on the hundred point scale that indicates risk of recurrence. I don't, of course, know exactly how the overall score is calculated, but I don't think they would report a range of socres for ER, PR, and HER2, which they do, if the range of scores had no bearing on the overall score. .

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 12:36PM - edited Jun 28, 2009 03:42PM by Seabee Given Grade 3 and that high Onco DX score, chemo is definitely in order, but  I do not advise anyone to meddle with A in any combination, or with its near cousin Ellence, since they are both cardiotoxic, which means that sooner or later (and it might be much later) they can lead to congestive heart failure. This happens in only 4-5% of cases, but the stakes are very high. In Meg's case A makes more sense than it would in yours, given the fact that she is Stage III and triple negative. However, A is generally most effective against Her2+ tumors. I don't know of any evidence that AC is more potent than TC, and ACT or AC+T are just ways of fudging the issue--if you include both, no one can be sure which one (if either) is more effective. I believe a clinical trial is underway which compares them head to head. Both do have side effects, but if your onco monitors your treatment carefully you should get the right dose for your body weight. You are also ER+, which means that you can respond to hormonal systemic therapy, so chemo is not the only weapon in your arsenal. A second opinion might be a good idea.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 05:46PM Seabee wrote: Here's what I'm finding out about radiation burns. Mine are especially bad in the under-the-breast area, where I tend to have trouble with rashes anyhow. I have large breasts, and it tends to stay moist and hot under there, especially in warm weather. I now have some dead skin under my treated breast which is turning white and peeling, leaving some raw, red patches exposed. My onco prescribed an antibiotic cream (silver sulfadiazine) to prevent infection. I apply the cream, and then cover the raw patches with a non-stick absorbant pad. The pad is pretty well held in place by the breast, but wearing a comfortable soft cotton bra also helps secure it. The antibiotic cream and the smooth surface of the pad allow the breast to move somewhat without being irritated. Tape is definitely out. Breast skin seems to be very thin--at least mine is. Tape can cause it to tear and bleed even when it is in normal condition. These non-stick patches are probably not as comfortable as a gel patch, but once in place they do much better than anything else I've tried.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2010 01:37PM Seabee wrote: By all means don't try to diagnose yourself, certainly not before you have more detailed information, and more time to do research. Breast cancer is a complex subject, so it takes time to get reasonably informed aboutd it. At this point you need to remember that most women who have breast cancer survive. That doesn't mean that you should be complacent, but it does mean that you should avoid overemphasizing the negative possibilities. These have to be taken into account, since they are effective motivators for getting through treatment, but they shouldn't dominate your thinking. After you have the results of your biopsy and other tests, you will have a much better idea what you are dealing with and what you can do about it.The more you know,the better you'll feel. In the meantime, be patient and think constructively.  That's easier said than done, especially in the early stages of the process, but brooding won't help.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 12:00PM - edited May 15, 2009 09:53AM by Seabee Med--The Oncotype test is now available for patients with 1-3 positive nodes. I took it at my request, and scored low risk (16), so no chemo. For me chemo would have resulted in zero benefit and some risk, so I saw no point in doing it. I finished rads two months ago and am now on Femara. So far, no side effects. If there are any little things circulating in you, the tamox or A/Is should take care of them. My rad onc was involved in the development of the oncotype test, and he told me he thought I had made the right decision, that for years oncs had been prescribing chemo for node positives knowing very well that many of them would not benefit from it and that a few of them would die of it. He also said that the science behind the oncotype test was much more extensive than that behind any chemotherapy regimen. You seem to have a conscientious onc who no only uses the oncotype test but also understands how to interpret it.  However, if you feel you need one, by all means get a second opinion.
Posts.Title: oncotype DX test MED lynninpa

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 01:49PM Seabee wrote: hrf--note that I said ILC *often* doesn't respond well to chemo. Some types of ILC do respond well to it, ususally the types considered more aggressive. I can't tell from your sig what features of yours would put it in the responsive group, but there must be some. You're right that all oncs don't agree, however.  Jeanne_D--It is true that women with node involvement have a somewhat worse prognosis. Since node involvement means that the cancer is either aggressive or has been there for a while, this is not surprising. It doesn't mean that the cancer can go anywhere. In some cases cancer spreads without ever showing up in the nodes, and in other cases when it is in the nodes, it doesn't spread. The purpose of the nodes is to trap foreign bodies, including cancer cells, not to give them an access route. The specific genetic makeup of the tumor is a more accurate indicator of how likely it is to spread than whether or not it shed some cells that were trapped in the nodes.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2010 04:18PM - edited May 2, 2010 04:19PM by Seabee Cheryl--I certainly hope it isn't congestive heart failure, but that is one serious side effect of AC. You were diagnosed at a time when AC was the preferred aggressive treatment for breast cancer. By the time I was diagnosed in 2008, some studies were available which led me to refuse to do AC on the grounds that it wasn't very effective on my type of tumor, and furthermore had this possible very serious side effect. Since then, AC is recommended less often, mainly for highly aggressive tumors, but only after a lot of women were exposed to the risk of congestive heart failure unnecessarily.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 03:36PM Seabee wrote: Tiptop--If you had a lumpectomy, radiation is standard protocol, whether your margins were clear or not.  If you do not have rads after a lumpectomy, your risk of local recurrence increases significantly.  The ideal is to have both clear margins and rads. Most oncologists prefer to do one treatment at a time, so you would normally start tamox after finishing rads, though some people do them simultaneously. The downside of that is that you double the possibility of side effects. Surgeons do not agree on how big a margin needs to be. As Mandy indicates, a 2mm margin is often considered clear enough, but some surgeons feel more comfortable with bigger margins. If you don't trust your oncologist's judgment, you definitely need to consult another one.

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2009 03:43PM Seabee wrote: Tiptop--Believe me, I completely understand why anyone would want to question standard protocol. The thing about radiation therapy is that it has been around for a very long time and its value is pretty much taken for granted (which doesn't mean that it works every time, but the chances are good that it will help). The waters are a lot muddier with chemotherapy, because its effectiveness seems to vary widely with different tumor types, and some of its side effects are deadly--as opposed to merely nasty and unpleasant. I'm sure there have been studies of brachytherapy which you can find on the internet. Don't assume that you can't follow articles in medical journals. Most of them are perfectly understandable to anyone who can read. I got most of my informaiton from these sources.

The breastcancer sites on the oncotype test need updating, since the test is now available to patients with 1-3 positive nodes. In my case it became a factor in a decision not to do chemo. One of the breastcancer sites also implies that if you seem to need chemo and do it, you will certainly be protected against recurrence, which overstates the benefit. At best, chemo will increase your odds of disease-free survival  for five years by a few percentage points. But with a recurrence score of 33, Grade 3, etc., it would certainly be advisable to do it.

TC is a very potent chemo, and while it has side effects, none of them are potentially fatal. The NCCN guidelines are merely recommendations which establish a "standard of practice" within which oncos can operate safely. No one can sue a doctor for malpractice if s/he stays within those guidelines. That does not keep more daring doctors from experimenting, because NCCN has no enforcement power. I see a lot of overtreatment going on out there, often because patients are terrified by the diagnosis, and are even willing to risk their lives to be sure that they've done everything possible. Your favorite onc sounds like a wise and reasonable person who is keeping up with her field. I'd trust her.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 11:42AM Seabee wrote: Sweeetpam, I'm with the RN.  As my husband says, a doctor is not your boss; s/he is your employee. S/he is an expert (one among many) who gives you advice, but you are free to get and follow better advice at any time. I notice that many oncologists like to do chemotherapy, just as surgeons like to do surgery. In the case of breast cancer, surgery is mostly essential, so the surgeon doesn't have to sell his or her service. Chemotherapy is often optional, and looking at the posts on this board I see a lot of people with low risk doing chemo anyhow, probably at the urging of an oncologist. Now I'm not saying that this is dishonest. Most people like to feel that their work benefits others, and people with a potentially deadly illness like to believe that some treatment or other will help them survive. In this situation your best defense is knowledge. You need to know exactly what the benefits and risks of your options are, get more than one opinion, and make your own informed decision. This requires more work than just doing what the doctor ordered, but it can certainly pay off.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 03:21PM Seabee wrote: From reading posts here for about a year I get the impression that it is not unusual to have a clear mammo and find a lump (or whatever) not long afterwards. I think this is because a large number of cells in a tumor may divide at around the same time. In other words, a tumor can double or virtually double in size very quickly, and then it may be a while before it does this again--depending on the mitotic rate, which is probably the most important number in the Nottingham scale. I didn't have a lump but rather what is called a "thickening," very common with ILC and not usually palpable like a lump. Also it often doesn't show up on mammo, though that's how mine was caught as an area of suspicious density. It did show up on untrasound and especially MRI. Self exams can be hit or miss, but my mother discovered her tumor while she was dressing. She survived for 36 years after surgery and rads without a recurrence. No chemo decisions to make  in those days.

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2008 01:41PM - edited Nov 29, 2008 01:47PM by Seabee Caroline, An aggressive 3 might be considered a reason for AC+T.  My impression is that IDC tends to be more aggressive than classic ILC, and a Grade 3 would intensify that factor, so in your case an A regimen might be a reasonable option. Only you can decide if the possible gain would be worth a slightly increased risk of a very undesirable side effect. The Oncotype Dx test for node negatives consists of a recurrence score, based on a genomic assessment of your tumor. Low risk is under 18. Intermediate risk 18-30, high risk 30 or above. It also consists of three graphs. One shows the correlation between score and percentage of risk, the other two indicate the relative effectiveness of hormone therapy compared to combined therapy (chemo plus Tam).  These remain about the same if the recurrence score is 15 or less, but after that the incidence with hormone therapy alone starts to rise, while the incidence on combined therapy rises much less. At he end of ten years there is a thirty point difference if your recurrence score is 50.  The graphs give a much clearer picture of where you stand than the numerical score alone. Finally,  the test indicates how positive or negative your ER, PR,and HER2 status is.  I would encourage you and everyone to obtain copies of your medical records, including the Oncotype Dx test results.  They are yours, bought and paid for, and for the most part they are easy to understand and much more informative than anything you can get from a conversation with your oncologist. The oncologist is an expert, but he also has his or her attention divided among a dozen or so patients. You have more time and incentive to look out for yourself than he has, which is why the American Cancer Society encourages patients to be proactive and take a major role in managing their treatment. This may be a headache, but it is also a necessary form of self-preservation. If your oncologist presents you with options and gives you a choice, I would say you have a good oncologist, because this is a rapidly evolving field in which there are few absolutes. If you are interested in the range of regimens that oncologists have to choose from, check out the NCCN website at http://www.nccn.org.  There you will find AC+T, TAC, and the latest arrival, TC, along with many others. You will also find practice guidelines which indicate how differnt types of breast cancer can be treated, when a genomic test becomes a useful part of decision-making, etc. Ferni,  On the issue of ILC, which I have, see http://www.news-medical.net/print_article.asp?id=7087 and http://annonc.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/17/8/1228 The full text of the latter indicates that "all . . .chemotherapy was anthrocycline based."  I assure you that given my circumstances I have no intention of coming anywhere near an anthrocyline, much less of letting someone infuse it in my veins. TC seems to be the best possibility for lobular, but I don't know of any studies where its efficacy for this particular subtype has been demonstrated. It's a shot in the dark, but probably better than AC, as far as I can determine from the limited informaiton available. I can't see any reason why your Dx score would be high, unless your ILC is pleomorphic. (You might find that out from your pathology report.) I called Genomic Health and asked what the scores were mainly based on, and was told that HER2 status (47%) and hormone receptivity were major factors. If your HER2 is negative and your ER positive, you could reasonably ask them what the high recurrance score was based on. I assume my low score was based on negative HER2 and high ER, but from all diagnostic indications yours should be lower than mine. I didn't have a choice about axillary dissection. My surgeon followed the standard practice of proceding with it if any cancer AT ALL is found in the sentinel nodes. As a result I lost 20 additional nodes which had no cancer in them. This was the worst part of the operation, but the only side effect I have is a little numbness in the underarm area. I repidly regained range of motion in my arm and had no lymphedema, which is probably a much more typical outcome. At least I have some reason to hope that the lymphatic involvement was limited.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 01:50PM - edited Jan 5, 2009 01:59PM by Seabee The problem mbradford points out is not just a problem with interpreting the Oncotype DX test. It is a problem that is pervasive in breast cancer treatment, especially in connection with chemotherapy. Just the other day I came across an article titled "Chemotherapy criticised by Australian oncologists" in which this same distinction between absolute and relative benefit was emphasized.  According to these Australian oncologists, not only patients but other oncologists are often unclear about this distinction, and if you mistake relative benefit for absolute benefit, you tend to overestimate the value of chemo in preventing relapse and insuring survival. You can find the article by entering the headline in your browser. It is on the cancerfighter.wordpress.com site and dated 8/29/2008. I don't have the entire URL on my printout. My impression is that chemo is a huge industry that thrives on the anxiety of people who have been diagnosed with breast cancer, particularly their fear of recurrence and spread. Drug companies profit from these drugs. Some oncologists administer the drugs themselves and therefore profit directly from them, as well as collecting an infusion fee. A basic 4x course of chemo costs around  $18,000.  More elaborate regimens cost much more. Since patients would rather believe that chemo will increase their chances of survival by 7% ranther than by a negligible 1 or 2%, they are unlikely to question the more attractive prospects suggested by relative benefit figures. This is partly why I suggested to Moody that she look at the St. Luke's study of patient noncompliance with adjuvant therapy. The 61 patients who failed to complete chemo or rads showed "no significant effect on 5-year local and distant disease-free survival rates." However, for the 294 who didn't complete hormone therapy, " Noncompliance with tamoxifen was associated with decreased 5-year local and distant disease-free survivals (87% versus 96%, 76% versus 87%, respectively."  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18809051

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 06:53PM - edited Jan 12, 2010 06:55PM by Seabee Some surgeons prefer to put the port in an arm because the location in the chest is close to a lung and a major artery, and accidents will (and do) happen. The port does not stick out of the arm.  It is under the skin, and is  accessed by a special curved needle called a huber needle.  The port is a good alternative to being stuck in the back of the hand, if you can get nurses to use it. I have had quite a bit of trouble with this. Not everyone (including phlebotomists) are qualified to access ports, and some people who are qualified don't want to be bothered. Ports can be used for blood draws as well as infusions, and they do minimize the damage done to veins by chemo. The arm location has cosmetic advantages, as others have mentioned, but it also rules out taking your blood pressure on the upper arm where the port is located, so there are drawbacks. But then in this business there are always drawbacks.  It's a question of deciding which negatives are least irksome.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2008 02:21PM - edited Dec 24, 2008 06:08PM by Seabee Adriamycin may still be useful in treating HER2+ and other aggressive tumor subtypes. It is  apparently not effective against most HER2- tumors, and the majority of  tumors are HER2-. Whether these possible benefits outweigh the risks has to be decided in the individual case, but there is no proof that Adiramycin works better tnan Taxotere, and Taxotere seems to be more effective against HER2-.tumors. What Caroline saw in the treatment room is reflected on this message board, where there are many posts on TC. I would have done TC if my Oncotype DX score had fallen in the intermediate or high risk groups, even though the indications were that I would benefit more from hormone therapy. Since I was placed in the low risk group, with 0% benefit from chemotherapy, the decision was much easier.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 07:41PM Seabee wrote: yasmin--What I see here is some people with more advanced disease telling you to do what they did. But what you need to do is what's right for YOU.  Chemo is sometimes recommended on the basis of age. Young women do tend to have more aggressive tumors, but the fact is that you don't, so what's good for many young women may not be what's  best for you. Young women also have more time to develop recurrence than older women, but I don't know of any hard evidence that chemo will prevent a resurfacing of the disease 20 years down the road, or for that matter that it will have any appreciable effect on a tumor of your type--especially AC, which I, like some other posters, would encourage you to avoid. It can be effective on more aggressive tumors, which sometimes makes it worth the risks. In your case it could be overkill. By all means seek a second opinion from an onc not at all connected to the one you've consulted, preferably one at a reputable breast cancer center.

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2008 01:06PM - edited Nov 28, 2008 02:51PM by Seabee The Oncotype DX test is now available for early stage, node positive patients, since it has proven reliable for these cases also. It is not covered by all insurance yet, but it is well worth taking.  I requsted it, since neither my surgeon not my oncologist suggested it.  As a result, I proved to have a low risk of recurrence, and was able to forego chemo. Chemo is acceptable if it will help you, but it does not help everyone, and it would not have helped me. If you test as high risk, that's another matter. In that case the Oncotype Dx test can help you accept the necessity of doing chemo.. As my Dx suggests, just having a few positive nodes will not prevent you from being low risk. That's a a theraputic distinction which genomic testing tends to discredit. On the test a crucial distinction exists between 3 or fewer positive nodes and 4 or more, rather than between 0 and 1..

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 06:23PM - edited Dec 26, 2008 06:30PM by Seabee Artsee-- Good question. I'm not doing chemo because my Onco DX score was 16, and because the graph indicated that for node-positive patients that meant zero benefit from chemo. I have the port because I had agreed to do TC before we got the results of Onco DX, which changed the equation considerably. However, I also have deep veins that are hard to locate, so I'm keeping the port for awhile in hopes of avoiding more wear and tear on the small veins in my hand. In standard treatment node positive automatiacally means chemo, but one advantage of the Onco DX test is that it relies on tumor genetics rather than on whether or not some stray cells have made their way to the lymph nodes--which is where they'll probably wind up whether the tumor is aggressive or not. As you can see from my sig, my carciinoma is lobular rather than ductal,;which may be part of the reason for my low Onco 'DX score. Lobular tends to be less aggressive and more resistant to chemo,than ductal, but is usually ER+, so I'm relying on rads and hormonal therapy to finish the.job. Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 06:37AM - edited Dec 27, 2008 06:38AM by Seabee Renrei-- It is true that the Oncotype grading system was based on a limited sample, but its predictive reliability has been tested against much larger samples, according to their brocure and websites. And there is nothing wrong scientifically with reasoning back from outcome to causes.or contributing factors, especially if the results have predictive validity. It's done all the time. But it is true that other factors influence treatment decisions, and lymphatic invasion is one of them. Oncotype is not intended to be the sole basis for these decisions, and it wasn't in my case.  It just confirmed what I had already inferred from other evidence. I rejected my first oncologist's proposal of AC, partly because its effectiveness on classic lobular is doubtful, and partlly because of its cardiac toxicity. I'm sure oncologists give what is considiered a safe dose and montor patients closely, but people vary in susceptibiliaty, and no one can guarantee what will happen down the road. TC is effective and does not present a cardiac risk, so I was willing to try it.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2008 12:26PM Seabee wrote: Simvog-- I don't know where you're getting the information that the test is only for pre-monopausal women; that isn't mentioned in any of the literautre I've seen. Originally the test was limited to women with early-stage (I or II) node-negative, ER+  early breast cancer, since that was the data base used for developing the test. The test projects what the recurrence rate will be *if* you are treated with tamoxifen. The point of taking the test is to get an idea of what someone with your tumor's genetic makeup who does take tamoxifin can expect. The test ia nor intended to be the sole basis for treatment decisions, but it does provide useful informaiton On the basis of further research, the test seems equally applicable  to women with early-stage, node positive breast cancer, particularly in deciding whether or not they need chemotherapy. This application of the test is newer, but it is equally well researched. In standard oncological proctice, one positive node requires chemotherapy. The Oncotype DX test data base indicates that this is not necessarily true.  Patients with low-risk scores, whether they are node-positive or node-negative, do as well or better on tamoxifen alone. If you are sure you need chemotherapy, there is no need to take the test. If there is reason to doubt  the benefit of chemo in your case, then it might be wise to take it, And of course you should ask your oncologist not only for your score but for a copy of the entire report (and for that matter a copy of all your medical records). They're yours, after all, bought and paid for.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 01:31PM Seabee wrote: Texas, ILC is notorious for being hard to detect on mammograms. That's because it doesn't take the from of a lump, but tends to spread out, hiding in dense tissue. For the same reason, it is hard to detect in a physical breast exam, because it may feel just like any other firmer area in your breast. That's why ILC is often described as "sneaky."  It tends to show up more clearly on ultrasound or MRI, but they normally aren't used except to follow up a suspicious mammogram.

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2008 03:23PM - edited Nov 28, 2008 03:45PM by Seabee Hi Lisa,  There are a couple of reasons why oncologists keep treating patients with Adriamycin. AC + T was a standard regimen for a number of years, and it does work on HER+ patients and some other aggressive tumors, so there was a tendency to think that it was good for everyone. Then, too, In general doctors are  reluctant to stop prescribing something which seems to benefit their patients, and they may tend to dismiss research which calls a method they have used with some success into question. Practice, in other words, naturally tends to lag behind research. I encountered resistance from an oncologist when I rejected his proposal of AC + T and sugtested TC instead.  His response was that  A would only damage a heart that was already weak (not  true), that chemo was generally beneficial (not true), and that the Oncotype Dx test was a diversion for "women who wanted to know their recurrence score." Needless to say, I chose to work with another oncologist. The Oncotype Dx test.is a good way to determine your level of risk, and whehter you would benefit more from chemo or from hormone therapy. The test was originally intended for node-negative patients only, but it now offers note-positive assessment also. It is not,covered by all insurance, but it should be, because in the long run, by determining who actually NEEDS chemo, it should prove cost effective. I'm curious as to how cebula's oncologist knows that her ER+ is only 10%. The Oncotype Dx test describes ER in terms of a numerical scale ranging from 3.7 to 12.5.  My score was 10.9. Any score of 6.5 or above is positive.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2008 01:49PM Seabee wrote: Caroline-- Go to the NCCN home page.  There you will find a button labeled "Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology."  That will take you to a list of different kinds of cancer.  Click "Breast Cancer." That will take you to a  series of pages about differnt kinds of breast cancer, algorythms for diagnosis and treatment, etc. In addition to the path reports you should get notes your doctor or nurse practitioner made on each visit, and whatever other records the doctor has kept on you. You should get copies of reports that other doctors made (i.e. radiologists and cardiologists) on biopsies and various tests that were done. It is also good practice to record your visits with your doctor.  You can get small digital recorders that fit into your breast pocket. I've found that listening to the recording helps me pick up details that I missed in conversation, or confirms my hazy memory of exactly what was said.. If that node was closest to your tumor, which I'm guessing it was since it was found in breast tissue, then IT was the sentinel node. And the node or nodes closest to the tumor are the likeliest place for shed cells to go--unless there is vascular invasion.What did your path reports say about that? The DX test for node positive cancer tends to suggest that the most crucial distinction is not between no nodes and one node, but between three or less and four or more. With four or more there's a significant jump in rate of recurrence..

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 12:56PM - edited Jun 19, 2009 01:52AM by Seabee NAZsusan--apologies--the last number got left off the link, and of course another article came up.  I have now corrected this and checked it, so the link should work.  In any case the title is "Noncompliance with adjuvant radiation, chemotherapy, or hormonal therapy in breast cancer patients." The gist of it is that in this particular group of hundreds of patients, only those who were noncompliant with hormonal therapy showed a signicificant decrease in local and distant disease-free survival. I have noticed that a certain rivalry exists between radiation oncologists and medical oncologists. Each would like to think that his specialty is best. My radiation oncologist is the most talkative of the three specialists, and he told me he thought my decision not to do chemo was correct. He said that for years oncologists have been recommending chemo when they knew that many women with positive nodes didn't need it, and that the science behind the Oncotype test was far more extensive than the science behind any given chemotherapy regimen. In any case, I doubt that your doctors will argue with you.  They are your employees, not your boss. Your med onc may have opted for an aggressive approach to protect himself from a possible malpractice suit (The "We did everything possible" defense.), and has stayed safely within NCCN and ASCO guidelines, but what may work for the majority will not work for everyone, and you have good reason to think that it is not working for you. Chemo has a record of working much better for Her2 positives than for Her2 negatives, particularly anthracycline-based chemo. The taxanes seem to work better for negatives, but no guarantee there either, You didn't say whether your tumor was ductal or lobular, but lobular also tends to be less responsive to chemo, which is part of the reason for my doubts about its value for me.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 06:54PM - edited Jun 28, 2009 01:56PM by Seabee NAZsusan--I think your experience is all too typical, and probably unrelated to the fact that you are on Medicaid, though it might be related to your rural location.  Doctors at local medical facilities are more apt to lag behind developments in the field, such as the shift in breast  cancer treatment toward a more individualized approach, and such facilities tend to treat patients less successfully than large urban medical centers.. I couldn't agree more with everything you say. I had people congratulate me for taking an active role in deciding on my own treatment, and I also had people express concern about my refusal to follow my first oncologist's advice. Some people assume that established practice is necessarily best for everyone, but in a rapidly developing field like chemotherapy there are few absolutes. Even health professionals have trouble keeping  up with developments in the field. The only solution is to be your own advocate and get as informed as possible about BC diagnosis and treatment. This is not an ideal situation, but it's better than being pushed into inappropriate, unnecessary, and risky treatments.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 05:26PM Seabee wrote: Susie has explained it well. Chemo works best on aggressive tumors with rapidly dividing cells. In fact it attacks ALL rapidly dividing cells, which is why your blood counts go down and you lose your hair--those cells divide rapidly also, and the chemo doesn't know a hair-growing cell from a cancer cell. The oncotype test is a more detailed assessment of the nature of a tumor than the observations the lab technician includes in your path report. While no test is infallible, the oncotype test is highly reliable. And there is also quite a bit of research indicating that chemo is relativley ineffective on "indolent" (slow growing) tumors, and it does involve some substantial risks. If you forego chemo now and have ithe cancer come back, you will of course use it later. But if you use it now and have a recurrence, you can't use the same regimen again because it would be too toxic. All treatments of cancer have their drawbacks, so it's a matter of trying to identify the treatment plan that will work best for you and do the least harm. You're doing the right thing by asking guestions, and the answers should help you make the best decision you can make.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 06:25PM Seabee wrote: cubstan--Genomic Health is not yet offering the Oncotype test for patients with more than three positive nodes, because they don't have enough data yet on this group to consider the test reliable. Chemo tends to be most effective on more aggressive tumors, and since yours is Stage III and grade 3, it would seem an appropriate treatment for you. NAZsusan's situation is quite differentt. It is debatable that she is node positive, and even if she were node positive, chemo would not necessarily be beneficial.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 11:35AM Seabee wrote: I believe there is a clinical trial of three bisphosphonates going on now, one of which is Zometa. I don't have the URL, but you should be able to Google it. The infused bisophosphonates like Zometa are more apt to cause necrosis of the jaw than the oral ones, and they have long lasting effects, so if you take one it is best to avoid tooth extractions.
